event.title: The limits are working place
event.description:
At the moment, passengers taking liquid for their cabin baggage are constrained to containers holding only 100ml, which must be found to security staff in one, transparent, resealable plastic travelling bag of about 20cm (8in) times 20cm.

The limits are working place since November 2006. Their introduction ended any ban on liquids from the cabin imposed three several weeks earlier, when British police claimed they had foiled some sort of plot to blow up up to 10 planes using explosives concealed in drinks bottles.

Announcing the new plans, Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated the scanners would reduce “hassle” for travellers and also improve security.

“By making journeys through UK air-ports easier than ever, this new equipment may help boost the vital factor our airports play throughout securing the UK’s position as being a global hub for operate, tourism and investment, " he / she added.
Heathrow has revealed its spending Â£50m in order to roll out the technology over the next few years.

It is the first UK airport to install the equipment, which remember that it is trialling since 2017.

The airport’s chief executive, Bill Holland-Kaye, said it might make travel “less disruptive”, adding that the scanners could actually see what liquid was in luggage.

The scanners are set to be rolled out to other UK airports over the next few years.

Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said the newest equipment means “no extra pulling out your socks as well as your underwear, and having to part ways your liquids and along with take your laptops out”.

He added that aviation companies could well be paying for the adjustments, rather than the taxpayer.

The technology has already been being used by ALL OF US airports, including Atlanta’s Hartsfield-Jackson plus Chicago’s O’Hare.
